tutorial.main_title: Tutorial: Create Your First Wi-Fi Map
tutorial.main_desc: Welcome! Follow these 3 simple steps to see your building's Wi-Fi coverage. It's very visual, we promise!
tutorial.description_1:
First, we need to give the app a map of your location.
  • Go to the Plans page.
  • Click the 'Upload a Map' button.
  • Choose an image (PNG, JPG) or a PDF of your floor plan.

Once uploaded, your plan will appear in the 'Existing Maps' list.
tutorial.description_2:
Now, let's 'capture' the Wi-Fi at different spots.
  • Go to the Scan page.
  • Click the 'Scan' button on your plan.
  • The plan will open. Click where you are currently standing on the map.
  • Wait 3 seconds for the progress bar to disappear. That's it!

Move to another spot (e.g., a few meters away) and click your new position. Repeat this to cover the whole area you care about.
tutorial.description_3:
Time to see the result!
  • Go to the Maps page.
  • Click the 'Visualise' button on your plan.
  • On the left, choose a Wi-Fi network from the list.

The heatmap appears instantly! Red/Orange means a strong signal, Blue/Green means a weak signal.

‚ú® Tip: Hover your mouse over the scan points to see the exact signal strength and MAC address.

how_to.title_1: How do I save and compare scans?
how_to.description_1:
Want to save a scan to view it later?
On the Scan page, under each plan, you have two buttons:
  • Save: Click this after a scan. It downloads a small .json file with all your measurements.
  • Load: To review an old scan (or a colleague's scan), click this and select the .json file you saved.

how_to.title_3: How do I see channel congestion?
how_to.description_3:
On the visualization page, you see 'Signal Strength' by default. You can also see 'Channels':
  • Click the 'üîÅ Switch to Channel' button.
  • The list on the left will change to show Wi-Fi channels (e.g., Channel 1, Channel 6, Channel 44).
  • Click a channel to see how many networks are using it at each scan point.

This is very useful for seeing 'crowded' areas (see explanations).

explanation.description_1:
Signal strength tells you how good or bad your Wi-Fi connection will be. It's measured in dBm (a negative number).

It's simple: the closer the number is to 0, the better the signal.
  • -30 to -50 dBm: Excellent (you are close to the access point).
  • -50 to -65 dBm: Very Good (streaming, video calls OK).
  • -65 to -75 dBm: Fair (web browsing OK, but might buffer).
  • -75 to -90 dBm: Poor (unstable connection or dropouts).
explanation.description_2:
Think of Wi-Fi channels like lanes on a highway.

If there are too many networks in the same lane (on the same channel), it creates a 'traffic jam'. Everyone slows down, even if their signal is strong!

This map shows you the most-used 'lanes' (channels) in each spot. If you see a '5' on a point for Channel 6, it means 5 Wi-Fi networks are competing on that channel. The best practice is to set your Wi-Fi to use a less crowded channel (e.g., one where you see '1' or '2').

reference.description_1:
You can upload the following file formats:
  • .png (recommended)
  • .jpg / .jpeg
  • .pdf (Only the first page will be used and converted to a PNG image).
